title: 110_s880
content: The "Senate Family Leave Act" provides paid leave for legislative branch employees. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 is amended to include paid leave following birth for employees to assist in recovery, providing 7 contiguous workweeks of paid leave. Paid leave following birth or placement for adoption/foster care is granted to employees under the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993, providing 1 workweek of paid leave. The Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 grants paid leave to employees for the placement of a son or daughter for adoption or foster care, providing 1 workweek of paid leave. Definitions for "employer" and "eligible employee" are specified in the Act. The Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 defines an eligible employee as someone who has worked for 12 months and at least 1,250 hours in the previous year. Paid leave is granted to employees of the Government Accountability Office for specific circumstances. The Comptroller General of the United States and the Librarian of Congress will issue regulations to implement rights and protections for employees under the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993. SEC. 3. RESPONSIBLE PARENTING LEAVE FOR LEGISLATIVE BRANCH EMPLOYEES. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 is amended to include rights and protections related to responsible parenting leave. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 is amended to include responsible parenting leave rights and protections for eligible employees in employing offices not part of the House of Representatives. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 is amended to include responsible parenting leave rights and protections for eligible employees in employing offices not part of the House of Representatives. Eligible employees are entitled to 8 hours of paid leave to accompany their child to medical or school appointments. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 now includes responsible parenting leave rights for eligible employees in certain employing offices. Employees can take paid leave to accompany their child to medical or school appointments, with notice and certification requirements in place. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 allows employees in certain offices to take leave for parenting responsibilities, with certification requirements. The rights and protections of the Family and Medical Leave Act apply to this leave. Violations may result in appropriate remedies, including liquidated damages. Violations may result in appropriate remedies, including liquidated damages. Subsections (a) and (b) apply to the Government Accountability Office, the Library of Congress, and their employees, with regulations to be issued by the Comptroller General and the Librarian of Congress. The Board will issue regulations to implement the rights and protections established under this section, excluding subsection (c).
